results.title: Indian Patchwork APT group analyzed by Malwarebytes

incident_blocks.content:
1.1 Executive summary

Active since 2015, Patchwork is an India-based APT group which used to mainly target different entities in Pakistan via spear-phishing. According to a report released by Malwarebytes, this threat actor has changed its tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to for instance include the use of malicious RTF files to drop a variant of the BADNEWS Remote Administration Trojan (RAT). This variant (called Ragnatela by Malwarebytes) may have been created around November last year, and the campaign launched in early December, as show in this tweet.
 
Security researchers have been able to collect valuable information about this actor itself, because the group infected themselves with their own RAT, resulting in captured keystrokes and screenshots of their own computer and virtual machines.
 

1.2 What you will hear

Patchwork APT group has changed its tactics, techniques, and procedures.
 

1.3 What it means

In a new campaign launched in November 2021, Patchwork APT group has for the first time targeted several faculty members who focus on molecular medicine and biological research. These targets include:
  • Pakistan's Ministry of Defense,
  • National Defence University of Islamabad,
  • Faculty of Bio-Sciences at UVAS Lahore,
  • International Center for Chemical and Biological Sciences (ICCBS),
  • H.E.J. Research Institute of Chemistry,
  • and the Salim Habib University (SBU).
The interest in biological science has vastly increased for different threat actors following the outbreak of Covid-19 pandemic.
Patchwork APT is tracked by the wider cybersecurity community under the following names:
  • Dropping Elephant/Chinastrats (Kaspersky),
  • Quilted Tiger (CrowdStrike),
  • Monsoon (Forcepoint),
  • Zinc Emerson/TG-4410 (SecureWorks),
  • or APT-C-09 (Qihoo 360).

Most of the code used for its malware tooling was copied and pasted from various sources publicly available on the web, which explains why the name Patchwork was attributed to it in the first place.

The main new feature added by Patchwork APT in this latest campaign is the use of a new variant of the BADNEWS RAT called "Ragnatela" being distributed via spear phishing email. Ragnatela, which means "spider web" in Italian, is also the project name and title of the control panel used by Patchwork APT. Its features include:
  • Executing commands via cmd
  • Capturing screenshots
  • Logging keystrokes
  • Collecting list of all the files in victim’s machine
  • Collecting list of the running applications in the victim’s machine at a specific time periods
  • Downing addition payloads
  • Uploading files. 
In order to compromise its victims, Patchwork lures them into opening documents impersonating Pakistani authorities such as the Pakistan Defence Officers Housing Authority (DHA) in Karachi.
Patchwork ended up infecting its own network, thus enabling Malwarebytes researchers to see the threat actor running both VirtualBox and VMware to do web development and testing. The group also uses VPNSecure.me and CyberGhost to mask their IP address, but their machine displayed dual keyboard layouts: English and Indian.
 
As shown by the above important opsec failures leading to the threat actor infecting its own systems, the Patchwork APT group is not considered very sophisticated but a medium-skilled hacking-for-hire group. Moreover, this threat actor's interest is mainly focused on the Asian subcontinent (and Pakistan in particular), which is why we have only attributed a risk-level of 1 to this alert.
 

1.4 What you should do

No action required. The IOCs were added to our CTI repository in case our Managed Detection teams need to hunt for it.

2.1 External links 

Malwarebytes:
https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/01/patchwork-apt-caught-in-its-own-web/
 
 

2.2 IOCs

OCD Datalake CTI platform include IOCs provided by Malwarebytes that you may find here.
